awd_titl_txt: EAGER: SUPER: Non-Hexagonal 2D Boride and Borocarbide Superconductors
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

With this project, supported by Division of Materials Research, Profs. Kirill Kovnir, Kai Ming Ho, and Vladimir Antropov and their research groups at Iowa State University will be focused on the discovery of novel high-temperature superconductors which will greatly benefit society. High-temperature superconductors which are stable at ambient pressure have the potential to revolutionize modern technology in many energy-related fields: generation, transmittance, transformation, and transportation. Such superconducting materials are currently unavailable. Extensive previous studies on conventional superconductors pointed to promise of the systems based on light elements, such as hydrogen, carbon, and boron. In the current project, computational and experimental efforts are joined to find novel superconductors among layered borides and borocarbides of two or more transition metals. These particular target systems are severely understudied, and hold promise for tuning of the materials properties by means of metal or boron/carbon substitutions. The proposed research integrates computational and experimental studies to provide diverse training for graduate student researchers. The fundamental issues considered in the project are applicable to emergent energy technology. The acquired knowledge and established methodology may be applicable for functional materials development in other areas. 

TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This project, supported by the Division of Materials Research, is focused on the discovery of high-temperature superconductors in non-hexagonal borides and borocarbides of two or more transition metals. A combination of different transition metals allowed for realization of layers based on 5- and 7-membered B rings providing a lever to tune electron-phonon interactions in the boron network. The search for new superconductors starts with the wide computational screening of ternary and multinary metal borides and borocarbides containing at least two different transition metals with non-hexagonal B or B-C layers. A combination of Adaptive Genetic Algorithm and fast advanced machine learning algorithms is used to screen a large number of boride and borocarbides. The promising candidates are evaluated by higher-level theory and the properties relevant for the electron-phonon superconductivity (density of states, phonon frequencies, electron-phonon coupling) are estimated using DFT.  Using the DFT result, selected candidates are experimentally synthesized and characterized. The experimental feedback is provided both to structural optimization and superconductivity  groups to further estimate potential ways of optimizing electron-phonon interaction by aliovalent substitutions, in both, transition metal sublattice (to tune electronic properties), and boron sublattice (boron/carbon substitutions to tune phonon interactions).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project established a solid collaboration between two groups from different scientific disciplines, theoretical physicists and experimental chemists, who worked together on the discovery of novel boride compounds with potential superconducting properties.

Intellectual Merit. This proposal enhanced condensed matter physics and solid state chemistry fields by several contributions. The experiment-supported computational structural screening and optimization methodology, which was developed on the example of superconducting borides, can be applied to other systems when aiming at optimizing a specific functional property.

We developed a new high-throughput screening method to search materials with strong electron-phonon couplings. This method reduces the computational cost exponentially allowing  to perform computationally cheap and prompt screening of the large number of structural candidates for electron-phonon superconductivity. Our work generated several exciting predictions for novel boride and hydride materials with potential superconducting properties. When synthesized, the novel predicted superconductors which will greatly benefit society and enhance our understanding of superconductivity. The developed predictions posed a challenge to synthetic groups to verify the predictions. Our intensive tour-de-force experimental synthetic exploration of the predicted compositional space allows us to establish major obstacles, such as immiscibility of metals, preventing conventional synthesis of the predicted compounds. We explored and developed several unconventional approaches towards novel borides compounds and utilized resource at the Advanced Light Source at Argonne National Laboratory, in-situ powder diffraction, which allows us to understand the synthetic mechanism and guide future synthetic endeavors.

 Broader Impact and Dissemination. The performed research integrated computational and experimental studies of complex solids. Via the comprehensive discussions of the computational and experimental results by all project participants graduate student and postdoctoral researcher were trained in both fields where they will appreciate capabilities and limitations of each subdiscipline and develop an appreciation for the complexity of design of novel materials. This allows theorists to understand limitations of the experiments, such as vapor pressure, miscibility, and thermal instabilities (decomposition) at moderate temperatures. In turn, certain predictions with respect to not only stability at 0 K but also regarding melting region allow experimentalists to refine the synthetic protocols. Project personnel presented their research at national meetings, American Physical Society Meeting and published their results in peer-reviewed papers.

The involvement of a new generation of students in research was tackled. PI Kovnir delivered a talk to sophomore audience titled "What is Undergraduate Research" explaining benefits of earlier involvement into research. Graduate student researcher Andrew Porter took an active part in the training of the freshman undergraduate students in frames of Chemistry Learning Community class (CHEM 101). Freshman undergraduates were trained in safe performance of chemistry demonstration for outreach events in K-12 schools and on campus.


Last Modified: 11/10/2023
Modified by: Kirill Kovnir

Image
  • Graduate student Andrew Porter performing annual trainings the freshman undergraduate students from Chemistry Learning Community class (CHEM 101) in safe performance of chemistry demonstration for outreach events in K-12 schools and on campus.
